title: Generate reports for transactions and trade orders
body: You can generate reports for selected transactions or trade orders. For example, if you need to report transactions that result from trade order execution, or all today's transactions or trade orders. Depending on how often you need to produce the report, you can use one of the options:

title: Generate reports for transactions and trade orders
body: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search. This option is convenient if you need to produce the report only once.

title: Generate reports for transactions and trade orders
body: Generate reports based on the saved search. This option is convenient if you need to generate reports more than once – for example, if you need to report all today's buy transactions every day. You can also schedule report generation (see Schedule reports for instructions).

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: To generate reports for transactions or trade orders based on a search:

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Define the report scope:

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Search for transactions in the Overview (lower section) or in the Transactions view.

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Search for trade orders in the Trade orders view.

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Click the printer icon in the top-right corner of the view and choose the report options in the Report window that opens (see Report window in FA BAck reference for details).

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Click Generate report.

title: Generate reports based on the saved search
body: To generate reports for transactions or trade orders based on the saved search:

title: Generate reports based on the saved search
body: Open Transactions or Trade orders view, define the search criteria, and save the search (see Saving search views in FA Back reference for details).

title: Generate reports based on the saved search
body: Click the printer icon in the top-right corner of the view and choose the report options in the Report window that opens (see Report window in FA Back reference for details). In the Saved search field, choose the search you created in the previous step.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: To add your logos and fill in the content of the Contact us page in FA Client Portal, produce the files locally and upload them from FA Back.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: To change the logos and icons, change the following files in the public folder:

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: favicon.ico – A favicon for browsers.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: logo.[extension] (for example, logo.svg) – An icon on the navigation bar. The logo file supports a range of common image formats, including SVG, PNG, JPEG, JPG, and GIF.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: logo192.png (192px x 192px) – An icon used in PWA and as an Apple touch icon.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: logo_maskable.png – An icon used in PWA.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: To define the content of the Contact us tab in FA Client portal, create an HTML page contact.html. Place your HTML content inside the <div> tag and don't add the <html>, <head> and <body> tags as the page is embedded within the app.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: To upload your customizations:

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: Log in to FA Back and go to Tools → Administer → FA Client Portal → Upload customizations.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: Choose Logos, favicon or contact info and upload the files.

title: Logos, icons and Contact us page
body: Your new logos and Contact us page are immediately available in FA Client Portal as soon as you refresh the page.

title: File formats for importing postings
body: Postings are imported in FA in a CSV file or in an XLSX file, with the file columns described below. The file is based on column headers you can define in the first row of the import file – you can specify the columns in any order, and the system recognizes values in each column based on the text in the header row. After the first row, each row in the file should correspond to one posting. You can also skip the header row if the columns in your file are put in the same order as in the template file and in the table below.

title: File formats for importing postings
body: You can define the following properties of the import file in Preferences → Importing → File format (see Preferences - Importing for details):

title: File formats for importing postings
body: CSV file delimiter. By default, FA is configured to accept semicolon-separated values. You can change it to another character.

title: File formats for importing postings
body: Encoding: UTF-8 or Windows-1252. By default, Windows-1252 is used. Choose UTF-8 if your import data includes non-ASCII characters, for example, such letters as "å", "ä", "č", "ē".

title: File formats for importing postings
body: The file columns are described below.

title: File formats for importing postings
body: Download the CSV file templates here:

title: File formats for importing postings
body: FAFormat_postings.csv

title: Updating postings
body: You can update existing postings or market price entries by importing a new file with corrected data. The system identifies the posting to update by the posting external ID (po.extId), transaction external ID (po.transactionExtId), bank account number (po.bankAccountNumber), and security code (po.securityCode), so these fields must be filled in.

title: Updating postings
body: Specify if you want to keep the old values in each field:

title: Updating postings
body: To replace the field value, specify the new value in the import file.

title: Updating postings
body: To keep the existing field value saved in the system, add three stars *** in the field. Note: if you import an empty field without ***, the field value previously saved in the system is removed.

title: Preferences - Transactions
body: Transaction preferences allow you to set the options available in the fields when defining the information of a transactions in the Transaction window. Transaction type preferences allow you to control how your transactions affect your portfolio's contents.

title: Transaction cost types
body: Transaction cost types preferences allow you to define the cost types available for transactions. The cost types are used to categorize the costs and fees recorded to transactions: for example, transaction cost types can include advisory fees, custodian fees or broker commissions.

title: Transaction cost types
body: Transaction cost types can be defined in the Transaction cost types window in the Preferences. A cost type consists of a name and a type: the name is used to view and choose the type in the user interface and the type is used to identify the cost type.

title: Transaction cost types
body: In addition, you can categorize your transaction cost types, allowing you to associate a category to each of your transaction cost types. You can categorize your transaction cost types as Portfolio (investment service costs), Security (product costs) or 3rd (third party payments), and then further as Not categorized (default), One-off charges, On-going charges, Charges related to transactions, Charges related to ancillary services or Incidental charges, or from up to five additional Other cost categories. Cost category of a transaction cost type is utilized in ex-post cost analysis: when a category is set to a transaction cost type, the amount of the cost is summed into the selected cost category. For example, you can categorize the brokerage fees you record on your transactions as Charges related to transactions., when the amount of brokerage fee you enter into your transaction is considered as charges related to transactions in ex-post cost reporting.

title: Transaction types
body: Transaction type preferences allow you to see the transaction types available in the system together with the characteristics and effects of the defined transaction types. Transaction types are relevant when creating transactions: the transaction type selected for a transaction determines what kind of a combination of effects the transaction has on the portfolio.

title: Transaction types
body: For example, a transaction type "Sell" has a positive cash effect (e.g. money is deposited to portfolio's account with the transaction), negative amount and FIFO effects (e.g. a sell reduces the amount of the security in the portfolio), a sell would realize profits or losses and finally, taxes and costs reduce the trade amount of a sell (e.g. when there is a cost recorded to a sell of a security, the cost is deducted from the original trade amount and reduces the money you will actually get from the sell).

title: Transaction types
body: Do not modify the standard transaction types' effects - instead, create a new transaction type and use one of the existing types as an example. Transaction type effects often work as a combination, and changing one and not the other might not have a desirable outcome - avoid making your own combinations.

title: Transaction types
body: Transaction types are defined with the basic information of the transaction type (code and name) and through relevant effects for each transaction type. When creating a new transaction type, effects are by default No effect or similar.

title: Transaction types
body: Type code*

title: Transaction types
body: Unique transaction type code that separates it from other transaction types.

title: Transaction types
body: Short name*

title: Transaction types
body: Short name for the transaction type, which is used in the reports as the abbreviation of the transaction type. Transaction's short name can be translated into different languages, while the transaction type's type code is used to identify the transaction types within the system and cannot be translated.

title: Transaction types
body: Name*

title: Transaction types
body: Name of the transaction type.

title: Transaction types
body: Cash effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Adds cash or Reduces cash. The cash effect describes the effect the transaction has on the cash balance of the account linked to the transaction. For example, a "Buy" transaction reduces cash and a "Sell" adds cash on the portfolio's account by the trade amount of the transaction.

title: Transaction types
body: Net effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Add or Reduce. The net effect affects the transaction's net cash flow to the portfolio. If there is no net cash flow on the transaction, then any effect the transaction has on the market value of the portfolio will affect the portfolio's performance (TWR). Net effect would counter these effects otherwise. The net effect works differently depending on the transaction type's cash effect: when the transaction doesn't have cash effect, then the net cash flow is directly depending on net effect and transaction's trade amount (for example, "Add" transaction type has the net effect "add" => positive net cash flow, and "Remove" transaction type has the net effect "reduce" => negative net cash flow). However, if the transaction also has a cash effect, the net cash flow of the transaction is the combination of the cash and net effects: "add" cash and net effects => positive net cash flow; "add" cash but "reduce" net effect => negative net cash flow; "reduce" cash but "add" net effect => negative net cash flow; "reduce" cash and net effects => positive net cash flow. For example, "Withdrawal" transaction type has the cash effect of "reduce" and the net effect "add", which results in a negative net cash flow effect.

title: Transaction types
body: Amount effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Adds amount or Reduces amount. The amount effect describes the effect of the transaction's amount (i.e. units) on the amount of the security in the portfolio. For example, a "Buy" transaction adds amount and a "Sell" reduces amount of a position by the amount of the transaction.

title: Transaction types
body: FIFO

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Add, Reduce or Reduce all. FIFO describes whether the FIFO valuation method is taken into account. "No effect" means that the valuation method is not taken into account. "Add" means that the transaction is "in" and adds the amount of the security. "Reduce" means that the transaction is "out" and reduces the amount of the security. "Reduce all" means that the transaction is "out" and reduces the amount of each purchase lot proportionally.

title: Transaction types
body: Return effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Adds return (profit) or Reduces return (cost). The return effect describes the effect of the transaction on the portfolio return. For example, a "Dividend" transaction adds return. From FA 3.9 onward, return effect determines whether a transaction is a profit (adds return) or a cost (reduces return). This allows you to explicitly control "Other profits" and "Other costs" in TWR calculation. For example, a "Dividend" transaction adds return and is considered as "Other profits". In addition, you can control for example where you want see the effect of kickbacks - even with positive cashflow, you can configure your kickbacks to reduce return (a cost), when kickbacks would increase your (negative) costs instead of reducing your (positive) returns.

title: Transaction types
body: Realized profit effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Realize profits/losses, Realize profits/losses by closing open positions or Realize profit indirectly. The profit effect defines, whether the transaction realizes profits - Realize profits/losses calculates realized profits from the transaction, such as sell, and shows it as “realized profit” and as “capital gain” for taxation purposes, while Realize profits/losses indirectly calculates realized profits from the transaction, and shows it only as “realized profit” but not as "capital gain". For example, a "Sell" transaction realizes profits (shown realized profits from performance's point of view and as capital gains for taxation purposes), while a "Remove" transaction realizes profits indirectly (shown as realized profit from performance's point of view but not as capital gains on tax reports). From FA 3.9 onward, the effect "Realize profits/losses" works on its own, independent of other effects. This allows you to realize profits also when your position’s units don’t change, not only when buying or selling.

title: Transaction types
body: Purchase price effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose the purchase price effect from the alternatives. Purchase price effect allows you to adjust your position's purchase price directly with your transaction's trade amount, even when your transaction doesn't have an amount effect. For example, transactions such as "capital return", "value adjustments" at year-end and "mark-to-market" for futures' handling often have a purchase price effect, only affecting your position's purchase value. For example "buy" and "sell" transactions don't have a separate purchase price effect, since they affect the position through the amount effect.

title: Transaction types
body: "No effect" - transaction's trade amount has no direct effect on the purchase price of the position.

title: Transaction types
body: "Add", "Add, record orig values", "Add in security currency", "Add in security currency, record orig values", "Add and set fx" and "Add and set fx, record orig values" - transaction's trade amount adds the position's trade amount in different ways. These options allow you to manage "value adjustments" at year-end for bookkeeping or "mark-to-market" on your futures' positions even for non-portfolio currency securities.

title: Transaction types
body: "Reduce", "Reduce, record orig values", "Reduce in security currency", "Reduce in security currency, record orig values", "Reduce and set fx" and "Reduce and set fx, record orig values" -transaction's trade amount reduces the position's trade amount in different ways. These options allow you to manage "capital returns", "value adjustments" at year-end for bookkeeping or "mark-to-market" on your futures' positions even for non-portfolio currency securities.

title: Transaction types
body: "Keep original purchase price", "Keep original purchase time" and "Keep original purchase price and time" - allows you to keep your position's original purchase times and values when changing a position to another. These allow you to maintain your FIFO chain and values for example for "exchanges" (keep original purchase time) or "subscriptions" when the new shares's purchase value is combined with existing lots (keep original purchase price).

title: Transaction types
body: Purchase price profit effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Unrealized profit or Realizes negative purchase lots. Only available when transaction type has a “Purchase unit price effect”. Controls whether adding or reducing purchase price affects unrealized profits. This allows you to control TWR calculation: value adjustments for accounting purposes don't change “original” purchase value and thus don’t affect TWR, while capital returns change purchase value from TWR’s point of view. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transaction types
body: No effect - purchase value is changed, but the “original” trade amount is not changed. Therefore, the unrealized profits in TWR are not affected.

title: Transaction types
body: Unrealized profit - also the “original trade amount” is affected and therefore the unrealized profits as well. In addition, if there is a difference in FX rates, which is possible if adding / reducing purchase value is done "in security currency" or with "set FX", the difference due to the FX rates is booked separately as "Realized FX profit".

title: Transaction types
body: Realizes negative purchase lots - same as the previous, but if purchase value is reduced with any of the "Reduce" effects AND the purchase value on a purchase lot would go negative, the negative part is recorded as realized profit. This effect is only used for “Capital return” transactions in Finland.

title: Transaction types
body: Unrealized profit via cost - affects the "original trade amount" of the buy transaction to which the cost is linked. Used, for example, for a legal fee that is added as a separate transaction ("Transaction cost" transaction type). The fee transaction must have the same Amount as the Buy transaction (to create a link between these tranasactions). The fee's Trade amount is added to the "original trade amount" of the buy transaction.

title: Transaction types
body: Market price effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No effect, Adds market value or Reduces market value. Market price effect allows you to adjust your position's market value directly with your transaction's trade amount. This is useful if you don't get daily market prices on your securities, and want to instead adjust the market value of your position directly with transactions, for example for "Private Equity" and "real estate" investments. If you feed market prices on your security, transactions with market price effect has no effect on your position.

title: Transaction types
body: Cost category group

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose a cost category group for your transaction from Portfolio (investment service costs), Security (product costs) or 3rd (third party payments). Within each group, select a further cost category from the next field.

title: Transaction types
body: Cost category

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose a cost category for your transaction from Not categorized (default), One-off charges, On-going charges, Charges related to transactions, Charges related to ancillary services or Incidental charges, or from up to five additional Other cost categories. Cost category of a cost transaction is utilized in ex-post cost analysis: when a category is set to a cost transaction, the trade amount of such a transaction is summed into the selected cost category. For example, you can categorize your asset management fees as On-going charges, when the trade amount of your asset management fee transaction is considered as on-going charges in ex-post cost reporting.

title: Transaction types
body: Date effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from Effect on position on transaction date to Effect on position on settlement date. The date effect allows you to decide whether you transaction affects your portfolios positions on the defined effective transaction date (booked date if defined, otherwise transaction date) or on the defined settlement date. By default transactions have an effect on position on transaction date, but changing the effect on position on settlement date is especially useful for example when the effect of a deposit or withdrawal should not be shown on your bank account before the settlement date, allowing you to directly track the settled, actual available cash within your portfolio. If you configure your transactions to take effect on the settlement date, the transaction will affect all calculations, including positions, profits and other analysis, only from the settlement date onward.

title: Transaction types
body: Ratio effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect or Relative effect on amount and unit price. The ration effect defines, whether the Ratio field of the Transaction window is available (no effect -> field not in use), and what kind of an effect the value in the field has on the security's amount and unit price.

title: Transaction types
body: Security 2

title: Transaction types
body: Security 2 defines if the transaction type has another security in addition to the security chosen in the transaction. Second security is involved, for example, in case of exchange transactions or call and put option transactions.

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from the following options:

title: Transaction types
body: “None” – The transaction doesn’t have a second security.

title: Transaction types
body: “Removes 2nd security” - The second security units are removed from the portfolio, starting from the older purchase lots. The number of removed units is based on the transaction ratio. If the second security is not removed entirely, the remaining purchase lots are left untouched. This effect is used in exchange transactions. For example, if you have 3 units and exchange them with a ratio 2 to 1, you will get one new unit, and one old unit is left in your portfolio.

title: Transaction types
body: “Removes 2nd security entirely” - All second security units are removed from the portfolio. For example, if you have 3 units and exchange them with a ratio 2 to 1, you will get one new unit and one remaining old unit is rounded away so that all old units are removed.

title: Transaction types
body: "Removes 2nd security and transfer cost" - All second security units are removed from the portfolio. All the costs and cashflows are transferred to the underlying security. The effect is used for exercising call and put option with the EXCC and EXCP transactions. This effect makes sure that the underlying cash flows and purchase value is considered correctly i.e. canceling out the cashflows when exercised.

title: Transaction types
body: “Based on another security” - Transaction involves another security, and the transaction effects determine how it is what the effect is. For example, issues are based on your ownership of the second security.

title: Transaction types
body: “Based on another security, transfer return” – Transaction has a second security. This effect keeps the old position in the portfolio and reduces the purchase price of the old position by the equivalent of the trade amount in the transaction. For the transaction date, the market value is split between the old and new position with the same percentage share as purchase value was transferred. This effect makes sure that the analytics values (Market value, TWR, cashflows) are preserved in spin-offs, where the removed security is first exchanged to a "temporary security" and the temporary security is exchanged back to the original security with a new exchange corporate action.

title: Transaction types
body: Group

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No, Yes - same or Yes - opposite. Grouping defines, whether the transactions of the transaction type are grouped to a separate position, and do the transactions affect the same or opposite position.

title: Transaction types
body: Tax effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No effect, Adds trade amount or Reduces trade amount. The tax effect relates to the upper tax field in the Transaction window (tax from trade amount). The tax effect describes the effect of the tax on the final trade amount.

title: Transaction types
body: Tax effect 2

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No effect, Adds trade amount or Reduces trade amount. The tax 2 effect relates to the lower tax field in the Transaction window (tax from fees). The tax effect describes the effect of the tax on the final trade amount.

title: Transaction types
body: Cost effect 1

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No effect, Adds trade amount or Reduces trade amount. The cost effect describes the effect of the cost on the final trade amount.

title: Transaction types
body: Cost effect 2

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No effect, Adds trade amount or Reduces trade amount. The cost effect describes the effect of the cost on the final trade amount.

title: Transaction types
body: Paid in capital effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Adds paid in capital or Reduces paid in capital. Defines how the transaction affects paid in capital value visible in Analytics+. The paid in capital is calculated based on transactions trade amount excluding taxes. If commitment type is “amount”, the paid in capital is calculated based on the transaction’s amount. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transaction types
body: Commitment effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No effect, Adds commitment or Reduces commitment. Defines how the transaction affects the total commitment of a position. The remaining commitment is then determined by subtracting paid in capital from the total commitment. For example, private equity transaction type "PE - Commit" increases commitment into a position.

title: Transaction types
body: Commitment type

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from Not defined, Price or Amount. Defines whether commitment is calculated based on transaction's amount (i.e. units) or price (i.e. amount x unit price). Mandatory to be selected (Price or Amount) if transaction has a "Commitment effect". (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transaction types
body: Distribution effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No effect, Adds distribution or Reduces distribution. Defines how the transaction affects distribution visible in Analytics+. The distribution is calculated based on transactions trade amount excluding taxes. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transaction types
body: Following buttons are available at the bottom of the Preferences:

title: Transaction types
body: Translate

title: Transaction types
body: Opens the Translations window for translating the transaction type, allowing you to save translations for the transaction type to be used in reports and the user interface, when a language other than the language of the transaction type is chosen.

title: Transaction types
body: Update

title: Transaction types
body: Updates the changes made to the transaction type to all the transactions of the updated type. The trade amounts and cash flows of the transactions in the all portfolios are re-calculated to take into account the changes made to transaction types, and the affected reports are re-calculated.

title: Transaction types
body: Versions

title: Transaction types
body: Opens the Versions window to allow you to follow the changes made to the information.

title: Transaction types
body: Clicks of the "Update" button are audited - user audit tracks user clicks on transaction type updates that might lead to report recalculation. Every time a user clicks Update in the Transaction type Preferences, user audit contains a message ”User [username] clicked Update in Preference/Preference”. Also, every time a report recalculation is started, system audit logs which portfolios' reports are recalculated and from which date onward. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transactions
body: Transactions preferences allow you to enable the Transaction window to ask confirmation messages and to set the settlement date automatically. You can also define the default purchase price (original or transaction) to be used on the reports, and the trade order statuses available for your trade order flows:

title: Transactions
body: Confirmation if the balance of the account is less than the total value of the transaction / Confirmation if the amount of the security in the portfolio is less than the amount defined in the transaction

title: Transactions
body: By default, neither of these confirmation messages is enabled: you can set the system to ask one or both of the confirmation messages from the check box. The purpose of these confirmation messages is to make sure that a transaction does not by mistake make the account balance or the amount of the security in the portfolio negative. When a transaction is saved, the system confirms the action with a Yes/No pop-up window, if the total value of the transaction exceeds the account balance, or the amount of a security exceeds the amount of the security in the portfolio.

title: Transactions
body: Set transaction's settlement date automatically based on transaction date

title: Transactions
body: Enable or disable setting the settlement date automatically. When enabled, whenever you enter a transaction date, the settlement date is automatically set a certain number of business days from the transaction date.

title: Transactions
body: Amount of business days to add to transaction's settlement date

title: Transactions
body: efine, how many business days ahead the settlement date is set from the transaction date. You can override this on the security level: if the "Enable settlement date" has been enabled for the transaction's security (or cash transaction's currency's), the number of days defined in "Settlement date" is used to calculate the settlement date for trades in that security. In addition to how many business days trades take to settle, the transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: Transactions
body: Set trade order's settlement date automatically based on transaction date

title: Transactions
body: Enable or disable setting the settlement date automatically. When enabled, whenever you enter a transaction date, the settlement date is automatically set a certain number of business days from the transaction date.

title: Transactions
body: Amount of business days to add to trade order's settlement date

title: Transactions
body: Define, how many business days ahead the settlement date is set from the transaction date. You can override this on the security level: if the "Enable settlement date" has been enabled for the transaction's security (or cash transaction's currency's), the number of days defined in "Settlement date" is used to calculate the settlement date for trades in that security. In addition to how many business days trades take to settle, the transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: Transactions
body: Use original purchase value in portfolio reports by default

title: Transactions
body: By enabling this setting, the original purchase value is used in the portfolio reports by default for transactions with original transaction information defined. By default, this setting is not enabled, and the portfolios reports use the transaction purchase value - however, if original transaction information is defined for a transaction, this information can be set to be shown on the reports by default. No matter which price is used by default, you can always change this selection when creating reports.

title: Transactions
body: Deleting a transaction is not allowed

title: Transactions
body: By enabling this setting, deleting a transaction or a trade order is disabled, i.e. the Delete button in the Transaction or Trade order window is greyed out, and you cannot delete transactions or trade orders manually from the system through the corresponding window. In addition, when enabled, transactions with status "Deleted" cannot be modified by other than ADMIN users. See also Permissions for usage for preventing deleting transactions for a certain user role with permissions.

title: Transactions
body: Available trade order statuses

title: Transactions
body: Enable the trade order statuses you want to be able to utilize in your trade order flows. The available trade order statuses include Open, Accepted, Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Partially executed in the market, Executed in the market, Settled in the market, Executed, Cancelled, Rejected and Expired. The statuses Open and Executed are always selected, since they are utilized by the system in different functions - the other statuses are free for you to choose from, depending on the trade order life cycle you want to maintain.

title: Fund company wizard
body: The Fund company wizard lets you set up a company or edit settings for an existing company in FA Fund Management app. When you set up a fund company in the FA Fund management app, FA creates a contact with the specified properties in FA Back to store the company information.

title: Fund company wizard
body: To set up a new fund company or edit an existing one, click the Fund companies button at the top-right of the NAV status view.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Name

title: Fund company wizard
body: Company name.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Contact ID

title: Fund company wizard
body: Company contact ID. Best practice is not to include special characters into the contact ID - only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Fund company wizard
body: Company business ID

title: Fund company wizard
body: Language

title: Fund company wizard
body: The language to use in reports.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Tax country

title: Fund company wizard
body: The tax country of the company.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Juridical form

title: Fund company wizard
body: Juridical form. The juridical form affects the taxation of certain transactions added to the fund portfolios.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Classification

title: Fund company wizard
body: Classification of the fund company.

title: Share class wizard
body: The Share class wizard lets you create, edit or delete a fund share class. When you create a share class in the Fund management app, FA creates a share class security with the specified properties in FA Back.

title: Share class wizard
body: To add a share class, click the button in the Fund details pane.

title: Share class wizard
body: To edit a share class, click the button in the Share class details pane.

title: Share class wizard
body: To delete a share class click Delete in the Share class wizard. You can delete a share class only if it doesn't have any transactions and isn't used in benchmarks.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class details and NAV calculation settings.

title: Basic info tab
body: Code*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique code defined for the share class. The code is used to identify the share class security and search for securities in the system. We recommend using numbers and letters (a-z) and avoiding special characters in the security code.

title: Basic info tab
body: ISIN

title: Basic info tab
body: The ISIN code of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Name of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class security type. Choose the type that is configured for funds in Preferences. If you have standard solution configuration, use Collective investment vehicles type.

title: Basic info tab
body: Holiday calendar*

title: Basic info tab
body: A holiday calendar that determines business days and holidays in the market to set a settlement date for subscriptions and redemptions. Holiday calendar options are configured in Preferences. You can also set the default holiday calendar used for new securities in Preferences.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class priority

title: Basic info tab
body: The order in which share class NAVs are calculated if there are multiple share classes. The NAV for the share class with the highest priority is calculated first.

title: Basic info tab
body: Decimal count for transaction units

title: Basic info tab
body: Number of decimals used in the units field of the client transactions. If the field is empty, the number of decimals set for the security type is used.

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price settings:

title: Pricing tab
body: Currency

title: Pricing tab
body: Share class currency – the currency share class units are quoted in.

title: Pricing tab
body: Initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set for a new share class). Initial price of the share class unit. Initial unit price is used for the first NAV calculation. The price you enter is copied to the Market data info tab in the Security window in FA Back.

title: Pricing tab
body: Date of initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set when you create a share class). The date for which the initial unit price is valid.

title: Pricing tab
body: Format

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price multipliers to use in calculations. For more information about multipliers, see the description of the Basic info tab in the Security window. Choose one of the options:

title: Pricing tab
body: Show price as is – Show the share class unit price without any multipliers.

title: Pricing tab
body: In percentage – Use "100" in both Multiplier fields for the security.

title: Pricing tab
body: Add manually – Enter the multipliers in the fields below.

title: Pricing tab
body: Decimals for share class NAV

title: Pricing tab
body: The number of decimals used in the share class NAV. If the field is empty, NAV is stored with 10 decimals.

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab defines costs and fees applied on the share class level. Share class-level fees are calculated after the fund level fees, in the order you put them in the Share class wizard. Click Add fee and enter the information about the share class fees:

title: Fund fees
body: Fund fees

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fund fees
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Amount or %

title: Fund fees
body: Fee percentage or amount in the fund currency, depending on the fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Decimals

title: Fund fees
body: The number of decimals used for calculating fees (0 to 10). The “Default” value is 2 decimals.

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category for the fee. The categorization is used in cost analysis and reporting (see View ex-post costs and charges in FA User guide), as well as for creating kickbacks (see Rebate contracts (kickbacks) in FA User guide).

title: Fund fees
body: Additional options

title: Fund fees
body: Additional fee setups.

title: Fund fees
body: Formula sets its own account

title: Fund fees
body: Set an account for the fee formula. For example, this can be useful with accrued account interest transactions over multiple accounts.

title: Fund fees
body: Include in income distribution

title: Fund fees
body: Include the fee in the income distribution calculation.

title: Fund fees
body: Use crystallization schedule for capitalization

title: Fund fees
body: Capitalize fees automatically on the crystallization date when you accept NAV. The crystallization dates are defined in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab. Fees are capitalized to the account that has “Fee capitalization” tag. If no account is marked with this tag, fees are capitalized to the default cash account.

title: Transaction fees
body: The Transaction fees section contains parameters for subscription and redemption fees and charging them automatically when you calculate NAV. Enter the subscription and redemption fee parameters:

title: Transaction fees
body: Calculate fee for net trade amount-based subscriptions

title: Transaction fees
body: The amount from which the subscription fee is calculated in net trade amount-based trade orders: order trade amount or the sum invested in the fund.

title: Transaction fees
body: Define default transaction fees

title: Transaction fees
body: Settings for subscription and redemption fees calculated automatically and included in the transaction:

title: Transaction fees
body: Cost percentage

title: Transaction fees
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Transaction fees
body: To set the fee as a fixed amount per transaction, enter "0" as a cost percentage and then specify the fee amount in the Minimum field.

title: Transaction fees
body: Minimum

title: Transaction fees
body: The minimum fee amount to charge.

title: Transaction fees
body: Currency

title: Transaction fees
body: Fee currency automatically set to the share class currency.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains parameters to calculate and equalize performance fee. In addition to choosing the fee parameters here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee formula in the Fund wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Hurdle rate

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The minimum NAV increase above HWM starting from which the performance fee is paid.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count convention to use in performance fee calculation with hurdle rate. If the calculation period is less than a year, the hurdle rate is adjusted proportionally using the day count convention you chose.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The initial high water mark (HWM) to use for the performance fee calculation. Usually, HWM is set to the highest NAV value in the share class. On the crystallization date, FA Fund Management compares the share class NAV to the HWM. If NAV is higher than HWM, the HWM value is updated to the current NAV value.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark date

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The date on which high-water mark is set.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account settings to handle deposits and withdrawals.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account number

title: Cash transactions tab
body: A fund portfolio account to record deposits and withdrawals to. If the field is empty, the account in the fund settings or the default account is used.

title: Tax reporting tab
body: Settings for the Finnish tax reporting: fund company business ID and fund business ID.

title: FX hedging tab
body: FX hedging settings:

title: FX hedging tab
body: FX hedge transaction type

title: FX hedging tab
body: Transaction type for accrued FX hedge transaction.

title: FX hedging tab
body: Portfolio

title: FX hedging tab
body: Portfolio that contains the FX forward.

title: FA audit logs
body: FA audit logs let you track user activities related to sensitive customer data and changes in preferences that can modify the business logic.

title: Customer information logs
body: FA records logging in and out, opening windows, making selections on Overview, searches, report generations, PDF and XLS exports. Each audit trail entry includes details about the user, time, and screen, and information the user accessed or exported.

title: Changes in system settings
body: FA tracks changes in system settings that can affect FA functionality and system logic.

title: User access
body: Follow the instructions below to set up access to FA Client Portal:

title: User access
body: Access for end users - Create a user and specify contacts and portfolios the user can access.

title: User access
body: Access for troubleshooting - Set up view-only access to client information for advisors, support service, and so on.

title: Access for end users
body: FA Client Portal provides end clients with access to investment information. The user can access:

title: Access for end users
body: Their own portfolios and subportfolios.

title: Access for end users
body: Portfolios and subportfolios of the contacts the user represents – for example, if the user represents their child or a company they work for. A representative can switch between the contacts in FA Client Portal by clicking .

title: Access for end users
body: To provide access to FA Client Portal, you need to:

title: Access for end users
body: Add a new user as described in Managing users in FA Admin guide. Assign the user CLIENT PORTAL role.

title: Access for end users
body: Set up the user’s access to client information stored in FA Back:

title: Access for end users
body: To let the user access their own investment information, make sure the user's contact is specified as a primary contact for the portfolio (see Portfolio window) and link this contact to the user in FA Admin console (to do this, follow the steps in Link a contact to the user).

title: Access for end users
body: To let a representative access the linked contacts’ information in FA Client Portal, add the user as the contact’s representative in the Contact window, Representatives tab.

title: Access for troubleshooting
body: Access for troubleshooting

title: Access for troubleshooting
body: View-only mode lets advisors and support service specialists access the same view as the client sees, without being able to make any modifications. To access client accounts in FA Client Portal view-only:

title: Access for troubleshooting
body: Assign your user "CLIENT PORTAL IMPERSONATE" role in FA Admin Console. See Assign user roles for detailed instructions.

title: Access for troubleshooting
body: View FA Client Portal for a contact in the impersonate mode using one of the methods:

title: Access for troubleshooting
body: In FA Back, right-click the contact in the Overview and choose "Impersonate in Client Portal".

title: Access for troubleshooting
body: Open your browser and enter the link https://<instance>.fasolutions.com/public/myinvestments/impersonate/<client's contact database ID>/.

title: Overview
body: Overview provides a quick glance at the client’s assets, profit, and available cash. The user can view aggregated data from all portfolios or for a chosen portfolio.

title: Total investments (all portfolios)
body: If the user chooses Total investments at the top, the app shows Current market value and Unrealised profits from all portfolios (including subportfolios) and a short summary for each portfolio. If a portfolio has subportfolios, the summary shows values aggregated from subportfolios.

title: Portfolio investments
body: If the user chooses a portfolio at the top, the app shows investment information for the chosen portfolio:

title: Portfolio investments
body: Current market value

title: Portfolio investments
body: Unrealised profits

title: Portfolio investments
body: Available cash

title: Portfolio investments
body: Top performing holdings

title: Portfolio investments
body: Bottom performing holdings

title: Portfolio investments
body: Security type allocation

title: Portfolio investments
body: Performance chart

title: Orders view
body: The Orders view shows the client’s trade orders. The user can view the list of orders in all portfolios or in a portfolio chosen in the drop-down at the top. If a portfolio has subportfolios, the Orders view shows orders from subportfolios as well. Orders can be filtered by transaction date, order type, and security.

title: Orders view
body: Orders in the list are grouped by status (Open, Accepted, In execution, Cancelled). For each order in the list, the user can view security name, portfolio name, transaction date, units, order type, and trade amount.

title: Canceling an order
body: The user can cancel an order in Open or Accepted status by clicking the icon. To make this option available for the user, add the portfolio to the portfolio group CP_CANCEL in FA Back.

title: Order details
body: The user can view the following trade order details by tapping a trade order:

title: Order details
body: Transaction type

title: Order details
body: Transaction amount

title: Order details
body: Security name

title: Order details
body: Portfolio name

title: Order details
body: Transaction date and settlement date

title: Order details
body: Number of units

title: Order details
body: Unit price

title: Order details
body: Gross trade amount

title: Order details
body: Cost

title: Order details
body: Net trade amount

title: Order details
body: FX rate

title: Order details
body: Security ISIN code and marketplace

title: Order details
body: Description

title: Transactions view
body: The Transactions view shows the client’s transactions for a chosen time period. The user can view transaction details by clicking a transaction. Transactions can be filtered by transaction date, transaction type, and security.

title: Transaction details
body: The user can view the following transaction details by clicking a transaction:

title: Transaction details
body: Transaction type

title: Transaction details
body: Transaction amount

title: Transaction details
body: Security name

title: Transaction details
body: Portfolio name

title: Transaction details
body: Transaction date and settlement date

title: Transaction details
body: Number of units

title: Transaction details
body: Unit price

title: Transaction details
body: Gross trade amount

title: Transaction details
body: Cost

title: Transaction details
body: Net trade amount

title: Transaction details
body: FX rate

title: Transaction details
body: Security ISIN code and marketplace

title: Transaction details
body: Description

title: Transaction details
body: The user can download the PDF transaction confirmation report by clicking the Download transaction confirmation button. If there is no transaction confirmation generated in FA Back, the document is generated on the fly. On-the-fly generation requires a custom JSReport transaction confirmation report installed. For details, see Transaction confirmation report (PDF) .

title: Trading view
body: The Trading view allows users to browse securities on the markets and create buy trade orders. Securities in the list are grouped by security type. The user can filter securities by Country and Security type and search by Security name.

title: Trading view
body: To provide access to the Trading view, add the user's portfolio in the CP_TRADING portfolio group in FA Back (for details about portfolio groups, see Portfolio groups in FA Back reference).

title: Trading view
body: Trade orders are imported to FA Back and can be further processed there and sent to a marketplace.

title: Security details
body: Security details show security information and display recent price change as a graph. The user can view:

title: Security details
body: Security information (security type, ISIN code, currency).

title: Security details
body: Performance over time (one, three, and five years) in percentage (also on a graph).

title: Security details
body: Buy and/or Sell buttons. To enable buying and selling options for a security, you need to add a "Tradeable" tag to this security in FA Back.

title: Security details
body: Documents (prospectus and KIID). To make the documents available to the user, navigate to the Security window in FA Back and input the prospectus and KIID URLs in the URL and URL 2 fields. Make sure the URLs begin with a valid protocol (http://, https:// or ftp://) or they will not be visible to the user in the FA Client Portal.

title: Buying a security
body: The Buy button opens a view to enter trade order details:

title: Buying a security
body: Portfolio to trade in.

title: Buying a security
body: Number of units / Trade amount - Trade order amount or the number of units to buy.

title: Buying a security
body: Trading method:

title: Buying a security
body: Units - Create a trade order based on the number of units.

title: Buying a security
body: Trade amount - Create a trade order based on the trade amount.

title: Buying a security
body: By default, all security types except for collective investment vehicles are traded in units. Collective investment vehicles are traded in trade amount. To change this, go to the Security window in FA Back and choose one or more options in the Trade type field: "Buy units", "Buy trade amount", "Sell units", "Sell trade amount".

title: Buying a security
body: Trading options (buying and selling) are also available in the Holdings view.

title: Holdings view
body: The Holdings view shows the client’s investments and lets the user buy and sell securities. The user can view the list of securities in all portfolios or in a portfolio chosen in the drop-down at the top. If a portfolio has subportfolios, the Holdings view shows values aggregated from subportfolios.

title: Holdings view
body: Holdings in the list are grouped by security type. For each holding in the list, the user can view its ISIN code, number of units, purchase value, total market value and unrealized profit since start.

title: Holding details
body: The user can view the following holding details by tapping a holding:

title: Holding details
body: Latest market price with the date

title: Holding details
body: Market price history chart

title: Holding details
body: Number of units

title: Holding details
body: Purchase value

title: Holding details
body: Market value

title: Holding details
body: Change % since start

title: Holding details
body: Unrealised profits since start

title: Holding details
body: Security type, ISIN code, and currency

title: Holding details
body: Documents:

title: Holding details
body: Prospectus. To make Prospectus available in FA Client Portal, add the link to it in FA Back, Security window, URL field.

title: Holding details
body: KIID. To make KIID available in FA Client Portal, add the link to it in FA Back, Security window, URL 2 field.

title: Holding details
body: <Security documents>. To make a security document available in FA Client Portal, upload it in FA Back, Security window, Documents tab and add the "Online" tag.

title: Holding details
body: Buy and/or Sell buttons. To enable buying and selling options for a security, you need to add a "Tradeable" tag to this security in FA Back.

title: Buying and selling securities
body: The Buy or Sell button opens a view to enter trade order details:

title: Buying and selling securities
body: Portfolio to trade in.

title: Buying and selling securities
body: Number of units / Trade amount - Trade order amount or the number of units to buy or sell.

title: Buying and selling securities
body: Trading method:

title: Buying and selling securities
body: Units - Create a trade order based on the number of units.

title: Buying and selling securities
body: Trade amount - Create a trade order based on the trade amount.

title: Buying and selling securities
body: By default, all security types except for collective investment vehicles are traded in units. Collective investment vehicles are traded in trade amount. To change this, go to the Security window in FA Back and choose one or more options in the Trade type field: "Buy units", "Buy trade amount", "Sell units", "Sell trade amount".

title: Buying and selling securities
body: The user can also buy securities in the Trading view.

title: Documents view
body: The Documents view shows the documents stored on the client's contact, portfolios and subporfolios in FA Back.

title: Documents view
body: To make a document available in FA Client Portal, you need to save it with the "Online" tag.

title: Related links
body: Documents in FA Admin guide

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: # Code Required Name Description

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 1 po.extId No No. External ID of the posting. Used when updating an existing posting. If left empty, the system generates a running number as an ID.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 2 po.status Yes Status Posting status: ReadyNot finishedDeletedReported

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 3 po.parentPortfolio Yes Portfolio ID Text or number uniquely identifying a portfolio.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 4 po.postingDate Yes Posting date Date formatted as yyyy-MM-dd.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 5 po.effectiveDate No Effective date Date formatted as yyyy-MM-dd.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 6 po.accountNumber Yes Account number Bookkeeping account number.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 7 po.accountSetName Yes Account set Account set name.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 8 po.amount Yes Amount Posting amount: positive number for credit, negative for debit.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 9 po.reference No Posting reference. Free text, allowing you to fill in additional details on your postings.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 10 po.memo No Memo Posting memo. Free text, allowing you to fill in additional details on your postings.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 11 po.transactionExtId No External ID External ID of the linked transaction. If you provide this ID, the bank account number and security code are fetched from the transaction (do not fill them in).

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 12 po.bankAccountNumber No Bank account no. The number of a bank account linked to the portfolio.

title: FA Format for importing postings
body: 13 po.securityCode No Security code The code of the security this posting is related to.

title: Changes in system settings
body: Action Message Attachment

title: Changes in system settings
body: Change preferences

title: Changes in system settings
body: Create, modify or delete Account set in Preference → Bookkeeping → Account set User [username] created/modified/deleted account set [account set code] Changes in JSON format. In case of creating or deleting an account set, all account set attributes and accounts are listed. Modification shows the change, the old values, and the new ones.

title: Changes in system settings
body: Modify Analytics+ columns in Preference → Content and translations → Analytics+ columns User [username] changed Analytics+ custom column definition for [custom column code] Changes in JSON format. In case of creating or deleting a column, all column attributes are listed. Modification shows the change, the old values, and the new ones.

title: Changes in system settings
body: Modify permissions in Preference → Administration → Permissions User [username] changed permissions: [permission change] Changes in JSON format: old permission set and the new one.

title: Changes in system settings
body: Create, modify or delete a posting rule in Preferences → Bookkeeping → Posting rules User [username] created/modified/deleted posting rule in rule set [ruleset code] id [rule ID] Changes in JSON format. In case of creating or deleting a posting rule, all posting rule attributes are listed. Modification shows the change, the old values, and the new ones.

title: Changes in system settings
body: Import a posting rule import in Preferences → Bookkeeping → Posting rules User [username] imported posting rules in rule set [rule set code] Changes in JSON format: all attributes of all rules in the imported file as one list.

title: Changes in system settings
body: Create, modify or delete security type changes in Preference → Securities → Security types User [username] created/modified/deleted security type [security type code] Changes in JSON format. In case of creating or deleting a security type, all security type attributes are listed. Modification shows the change, the old values, and the new ones.

title: Changes in system settings
body: Change API or processes configurations

title: Changes in system settings
body: Generate or delete API token in Administration → API → Key management User [username] created/deleted API token [token name]

title: Changes in system settings
body: Change process configuration in Administration → Processes User [username] added/modified/deleted configuration of process [processId] Changes in JSON format. In case of creating or deleting a configuration, all configuration attributes are listed. Modification shows the change, the old values, and the new ones.

title: Changes in system settings
body: Manage extensions

title: Changes in system settings
body: Install, upgrade, or uninstall extensions in AppStore User [username] installed/upgraded/uninstalled process/report/widget/query/action/profile/formula [package name] [package version, except if it is uninstalled]

title: Changes in system settings
body: Manage system-level files

title: Changes in system settings
body: Rename a file User [username] renamed [file name] on directory [directory path]

title: Changes in system settings
body: Move, copy a file User [username] moved/copied [file name] from [directory path] to [directory path]

title: Changes in system settings
body: Delete a file User [username] deleted [file or directory name] from [directory path]

title: Changes in system settings
body: Create a directory User [username] created directory [directory path]

title: Changes in system settings
body: Upload or download a file User [username] uploaded/downloaded [file name] to/from [directory path]

title: Changes in system settings
body: Manage users

title: Changes in system settings
body: Remove users from groups User [userId] removed user [userId 1] from groups [group 1], [group 2]. User [userId] removed 2 users from groups: [group 1]. Affected users: [userId 1], [userId 2]. Full message listing all groups and users

title: Changes in system settings
body: Add users to groups User [userId] added user [userId 1] to groups: [group 1], [group 2]. User [userId] added 2 users to groups: [group 1], [group 2]. Affected users: [userId 1], [userId 2]. Full message listing all groups and users

title: Changes in system settings
body: Force password reset User [userId] forced password reset for user [userId 1]. User [userId] forced password reset for 2 users. Affected users: [userId 1], [userId 2]. Full message listing all users

title: Changes in system settings
body: Activate users User [userId] activated user [userId 1]. User [userId] activated 2 users. Affected users: [userId 1], [userId 2]. Full message listing all users

title: Changes in system settings
body: Deactivate users User [userId] deactivated user [userId 1]. User [userId] deactivated 2 users. Affected users: [userId 1], [userId 2]. Full message listing all users
